page.name: Strength
page.content:
Strength

Strength measures bodily power, athletic training, and raw physical power.

Ability Checks
Use general ability checks for situations like:

  • An attempt to lift a very heavy object.
  • Trying to force open a stuck door.
  • Attempting to break free from bonds.
  • Carrying something a long way.
  • Trying to hold on to a ledge or rope.

Alternate Skills
Skills that can be paired with this ability are:

  • Animal Handling. Attempting to use brute force to subdue an animal.
  • Intimidation. Trying to look scary versus trying to threaten someone with words.

Carry Capacity
Tiny (Strength x 15) / 2
Small Strength x 15

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 176

page.name: Ability Modifiers
page.content:
Ability Modifiers

Score +/- Score +/-
1 -5 16-17 +3
2-3 -4 18-19 +4
4-5 -3 20-21 +5
6-7 -2 22-23 +6
8-9 -1 24-25 +7
10-11 0 26-27 +8
12-13 +1 28-29 +9
14-15 +2 30 +10

Rules

  • The average for commoners is 10-11.
  • The character ability maximum is 20.
  • The monster ability maximum is 30.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 13, 173

page.name: Advantage
page.content:
Advantage
Advantage Roll 2d20 and take the higher of the two rolls.
Disdvantage Roll 2d20 and take the lower of the two rolls.

Rules

  • A player cannot have double advantage or disadvantage. They do not stack.
  • A player with advantage & disadvantage gets neither. It is straight roll.
  • A feat or feature that allows a player to roll again, they choose which die.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 173

page.name: Contests
page.content:
Contests

Contest Attacker Defender
Hide Stealth Perception
Grapple Athletics Athletics / Acrobatics
Shove Athletics Athletics / Acrobatics
Untie Knot Sleight of Hand Sleight of Hand
Disarm Attack Athletics / Acrobatics

Rules

  • Both PCs roll a d20 and add modifiers.
  • The higher check wins the contest.
  • In the event of a tie, the initiator loses.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 174

page.name: Dexterity
page.content:
Dexterity

Dexterity measures agility, reflexes, and balance.

page.name: Difficulty Class
page.content:
Difficulty Class
Very Easy 5
Easy 10
Medium 15
Hard 20
Very Hard 25
Near Impossible 30

Don’t make all your DCs multiples of five. A DC jump of 5 is huge.

- MrFarland

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 174

page.name: Conditions
page.content:
Conditions

A creature affected by a condition

  • A condition lasts until it is countered or
  • when the duration of the effect causing the condition has expired.

page.name: Blinded
page.content:
Blinded

A blinded creature cannot see and:

  • checks based on sight fail,
  • attacks against it have advantage,
  • its attacks have disadvantage,

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Deafened
page.content:
Deafened

A deafened creature cannot hear and:

  • checks based on hearing fail.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Exhaustion
page.content:
Exhaustion

An exhausted creature has:

Level Effect
1 Disadvantage on ability checks
2 Speed halved
3 Disadvantage on attacks & saves
4 Hit point maximum halved
5 Speed reduced to 0
6 Death
  • Additional points increase the level.
  • Suffer effects of current & lower levels.
  • Ends if level is reduced below level 1.
  • Long rest lowers level w/ food & drink.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Frightened
page.content:
Frightened

A frightened creature:

  • has disadvantage on checks & attacks while source of fear is in sight.
  • Can’t move closer to source of fear.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Grappled
page.content:
Grappled

A grappled creature:

  • has a speed of 0,
  • cannot benefit from bonus to speed,

The condition is removed if the:

  • grappler releases the creature,
  • creature is forced out of reach.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Incapacitated
page.content:
Incapacitated

An incapacitated creature:

  • cannot take actions or reactions.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Invisible
page.content:
Invisible

An invisible creature:

  • is impossible to see without magic,
  • is heavily obscured when hiding,
  • can be detected by noise & tracks,
  • has advantage on attacks,

Attacks against have disadvantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Paralyzed
page.content:
Paralyzed

A paralyzed creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws.

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Petrified
page.content:
Petrified

A petrified creature:

  • is transformed into a solid substance,
  • its mundane items are transformed too,
  • has it its weight increase by ten,
  • stops aging,
  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,
  • has resistance to all damage,
  • is immune to poison and disease, but current poison or disease is suspended

Attacks against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Poisoned
page.content:
Poisoned

A poisoned creature:

  • has disadvantage on attacks & checks.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Prone
page.content:
Prone

A prone creature:

  • can only crawl, unless it stands up,
  • has disadvantage on attacks,

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Restrained
page.content:
Restrained

A restrained creature:

  • has a speed of 0,
  • cannot benefit from bonus to speed,
  • has disadvantage on attacks,
  • has disadvantage on dex saves.

Attack against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Stunned
page.content:
Stunned

A stunned creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • can only speak falteringly,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,

Attack against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Unconcious
page.content:
Unconcious

An unconcious creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • drops what it is holding and falls prone,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

DM’s Tip

Adjust the size and price of regular items to make them bigger, smaller, or more ornate. Adjust the price and weight accordingly and a barrel worth 1 gp and 35 lbs, is now an empty cask.

page.name: Concentration
page.content:
Concentration

A caster loses concentration when they:

  • cast another concentration spell,
  • become incapacitated or killed,
  • takes damage from an attack or effect.

CON DC = Higher of (10 or 1/2 DMG)

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 203
